title: Visigoths
common: In works such as Manuel José da C. Felgueiras Gaio (Felgueiras Gaio, Manuel J da C. , Souzas, pp. 13) and Salazar y Castro (Salazar y Castro, Luis de, , Vol. I, pp. 45), references can be found regarding purported descendants of Visigoth kings following the dissolution of the kingdom. However, there exists no singular document that definitively confirms these connections. Therefore, such claims are "probably owes more to the imagination of later writers" (Medieval Lands, , Spain: Vandals, Suevi & Visigoths). In light of this, we treat these connections as hypothetical, in line with the principles of the scientific method (History Tracers, , Scientific method).

Knowledge never stops, and here we are not presenting the entire history of the Visigoth kings. To learn more about them, in addition to the chronicles and papers we mention, we suggest visiting the sites Medieval Lands and World History Encyclopedia (Medieval Lands, , Spain: Vandals, Suevi & Visigoths ; Mark, J. J., , Visigoth).
prerequisites: There are no additional prerequisites to understand this text.

families.name: Sisebuto's family
history: Due to the lack of information available from the period under study, Sisebuto's parentage and potential grandchildren remain unknown. The only confirmed detail is that he had a son who passed away a few months after birth (Medieval Lands, , Spain: Vandals, Suevi & Visigoths).

people.name: Egica
history: Similar to Sisebuto, Egica's parentage remains unknown (Medieval Lands, , Spain: Vandals, Suevi & Visigoths). However, according to Dom Alfonso III's chronicle, he was noted as King Wamba's nephew, Egicani consubrino Bambani regi (Dom Alfonso III, , pp. 18 ; Medieval Lands, , Spain: Vandals, Suevi & Visigoths).
During Egica's reign, the 16th Council of Toledo convened and made several decisions, including (Montero, Pedro, , pp. 553 - 587 ; Moreno, Luis A. G: Egica):

• I De judaeorum perfidia...peccatum Judae scriptum est stylo ferreo in ungue adamantino , super petram duriores effecti in obstinationis suae caecitate perdurant... quatenus aut convertantur ad fidem aut in perfidia perdurantes acrioribus sedulè mulctentur stimulis... [translation: I Concerning the perfidy of the Jews... the sin of the Jews is written with an iron pen on a diamond nail, they are made harder on the rock in the blindness of their obstinacy...so far as either they are converted to faith or those who persist in perfidy are punished with sharper spurs]
  • V De reparatione ecclesiarum vel diversis aliis causis... ut ecclesia quae usque ad decem habuerit mancipia super se habeat sa- cerdotem ; quae verò minus decem mancipia ha- buerit aliis conjungatur ecclesiis [translation: V Concerning the repair of churches or various other causes... so that a church which has had up to ten servants may have a priest over it; which, in truth, had less than ten servants, was joined to other churches...]

The persecution of Jews by Sisebuto and Egica, along with regulations on slavery, including women, are documented in other councils organized by the Centre d'Estudis, Debats i Tertúlies (CEDT, ESPAÑA VISIGODA: Los Concilios de Toledo sobre los esclavos de la Iglesia; y sobre la esclavitud y los judíos).

people.name: Witiza
history: When Alexander P. Bronisch studied Alfonso III's chronicle, he described part of it as "la maldadde la estirpe de Witiza" [translation: The evil of Witiza's descendants] (Bronisch, Alexander, , pp. 35 - 36). This conclusion stems from the severe criticism leveled at Witiza in the chronicle, including the assertion: " Istut namque Spanie causa pereundi fuit, sicut dicit scriptura: Quia habundauit iniquitas..." [translation: Because this was the root of Spain desctruction, as the written says: Because the inequity was always present...] (Dom Alfonso III, , pp. 18).

Regarding the situation in the Iberian Peninsula, Charles R. Haines informs us: "The old Spanish chronicles depict the fall of the Gothic kingdom as a direct vengeance from Heaven... a suicidal policy towards the Arians and the Jews." (Haines, Charles R., , pp. 12).

Finally, we must also consider what is recounted in Ibn El-Kouthya's chronicle about an invitation to the Muslims: "et dit à Rodrigue: "J'ai laissé là-bas des chevaux et des facouns d'une qualité incomparable". Le roi lui remit des sommes considérables pour cette nouvelle acquisition, et l'autorisa à traverser la mer. C'est alors que Julien se rendit auprès de Thârik, fils de Ziad, et lui suggéra l'idée de conquérir l'Andalouisie, en lui dépeigant ses richesses, la faiblesse et la lâcheté de ses habitants." [translation: and said to Rodrigo: “I left there horses and wagon in an incomparable sample”. The king gave him considerable sum to have a new aquisition, and he authroized to go through the sea. After this Julien he was until Thârik, Ziad's son, and he suggested the idea to conquest Andaluzia, when here reported your riches, weakness and cowardice of its inhabitants.] (Ibn El-Kouthya, M. A. Cherbonneau, , pp. 8 - 9).
Based on the information presented, let us reflect:

Reflection 3: About the End
Did Visigoth oppression contribute to the destabilization of the kingdom?
Was the invitation to the Muslims an act of desperation due to Visigothic atrocities?

Mathematics in History

Mathematical limits (History Tracers, , Natural Limits) play a crucial role in drawing conclusions about historical events.

The study of primary sources that only mention an Arab "invasion" can lead the reader to believe that the Visigothic kingdom was in harmony until the invasions occurred. This happens because, when grouped together, these sources reinforce a pre-existing narrative.

However, as we analyze additional primary sources that introduce new data and weaken the previous understanding, instead of having just one interpretation (sources supporting the idea of invasion), new possibilities emerge, such as the idea of other peoples arriving to help an oppressed population. Thus, we are faced with two different hypotheses (History Tracers, , Scientific Method).

With more data available, we can apply quantitative methods to evaluate both hypotheses and arrive at a conclusion closer to reality, forming the basis of a new theory.

exercise_v2.question: If we have an Iberian Peninsula king as an ancestor, do we also have Visigoth kings as ancestors?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: There is no documentation or chronicle that confirms the relationship between Visigoth kings and later monarchies, so we consider this relationship hypothetical. Therefore, it is safer to state that we either do not have them as ancestors, or they are likely our ancestors.

exercise_v2.question: Is Sisebuto a direct descendant of other Visigoth kings?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The Visigoths determined their kings through election. While some sons succeeded their fathers as kings, this was not the general rule. Due to the lack of documentation and lineage transmission, we do not know Sisebuto's father.

exercise_v2.question: Is Recaredo the son of Sisebuto?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: There is a contemporary chronicle describing the relationship, providing strong reasons to believe that Recaredo is the son of Sisebuto.

exercise_v2.question: Was there a slavery system during the Visigoth kingdom?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The institution of slavery has existed in human societies for millennia. Council documentation confirms the existence of a slavery system, including in the church.

exercise_v2.question: Is Menaia Ribeiro a descendant of Sisebuto, father of Recaredo, who also had the name Sisebuto?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: The existence of a figure like Menaia Ribeiro is uncertain. The absence of any chronicle mentioning a Sisebuto as the son of Witiza also casts doubt on the proposed relationship. At present, linking Menaia Ribeiro to Recaredo's father is more speculative than factual. This conclusion may change with the discovery of new documentation or chronicles.
